text: one reader asks whether it would have
been possible for Rwanda to achieve full
economic recovery without an autocratic
approach frankly I find when I travel
around four countries that people are
less interested in issues of democracy
or autocracy then we Americans often are
you go to people in the villages then
the things that they focus on our access
to clean water jobs healthcare getting a
school there and so far the evidence is
mixed about what kind of government is
to be more effective in getting schools
built clinics bill providing jobs
whether it's a democracy or an autocracy
there is a little bit of evidence that
at in poor countries autocracies may
sometimes be a little bit more effective
but also that autocracies have more
downside risk and can have more famines
more brutal repression so I don't think
there's a strong correlation there one
way or the other one additional point
I'd make though is that when we America
talked about spreading democracy and I
think this is indeed a value that it is
something that should be one of the
things we try to spread we tend to think
only of elections and democracy is about
so much more than holding elections and
especially about building institutions
that provide monitoring that my checks
and balances on authority on corruption
that can be things like freedom of the
press it can be free judiciary be an
opposition party it can be protection of
minorities and I think that if we were
to do a little bit more to try to
encourage those kinds of checks and
balances in a society rather than just
focusing single-mindedly on holding
election and then so stepping back and
letting things unfold that actually
people in these countries would be
rather better off
